advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZELAND AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones for this picture.</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The All-Purpose System</b> <br><br> The MTX Series is a new departure in micro-computer technology. Whether your needs as a user ore for personal programming, games playing, scientific or process control, educational or business use the MTX Series is already capable or very easily adoptable to almost every application. Glance through the standard features below - you'll see what we mean.<br><br> <b>Software</b><br> The MTX's 24K ROM contains several languages and routines which enable the novice or the experienced programmer to make full use of the machine. Standard languages are MTX BASIC, MTX LOGO commands, NODDY. ROM routines include on ASSSEMBLER/DISASSEMBLER with screen display of the Z80 CPU registers, memory and program, which can be manipulated from the keyboard. Machine code programs can be stepped through one instruction at a time, and easily called from within BASIC programs. A further feature is the Virtual Screen facility which enables the programmer to split the screen into a maximum of eight sections to work independently whilst maIntaining all full screen facilities. Pascal is available as on add-on ROM pock.<br><br> <b>Hardware - 32K RAM on the MTX500. 64K on the MTX512.</b><br> The MTX500 has 32K of user RAM as standard (64K on the 512), expandable to 512K plus 16K of video RAM, controlled by a separate Video Processor. Sixteen colours, 40 column text, 256 x 192 high resolution graphics with all sixteen colours available, and 32 easily moveable user defined graphics characters (Sprites) combine to make effective screen displays quick and simple to achieve. Standard outputs are centronics printer port, two ioystick ports, an uncommitted I/O port, 2400 Baud Cassette port, separate TV and Video Monitor ports, 4 channel sound with hifi output plus a dedicated cartridge port. Other standard features include the Z80A processor runnIng at 4MHz, real time clock, full moving key keyboard with 79 keys including eight 2-function keys and separate numeric pad.<br><br> <b>The Disc Based Computers from Memotech.</b> Designed to use the full power of the MTX computers the FDX and HDX make perfect busIness systems at prices which make perfect business sense. Both feature the CP/M operating system, giving Instant access to a wide range of proven application software. Available in October these feature:<br> • Full Western Digital floppy dIsc controller set with SASI interface for 4 drives, CP/M types 0 - 13.<br> • minimal latency, very high data transfer rates<br> • optional Colour 80 Column Board<br> • optional SilIcon Discs (1/4 Mb) which dramatically Increase the efficiency of 8 bit software to those of 16/32 bit software; increases life and reliability of mechanical drive<br> • permits single disc CP/M operation<br><br> <b>FDX Floppy Disc System</b><br> 1 or 2 5 1/4" Qume drives 500K unformatted, 347K formatted.<br> <b>HDX- Hard Disc System</b><br> 5 1/4" Qume drive, 500K unformatted, 347K formatted, 5 1/4" Winchester which may be 5, 10, or 20 Mb.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NASCOM 1 BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NICE AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As computing was a serious and professional subject, the humorus adverts was rare in 1983.<br> This one said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> When I told my Dad about NEC TREK, NEC's new personal computer, he wanted one right away.<br><br> I told him it has 10 programmable function keys; high powered graphic capabilities, powerful Microsoft BASIC included, and a 8-octave programmable musical tone generator.<br><br> He said it has lot of 'fun games'. <br><br> I told him how its memory storage can interface with cassette diskette or cartridge, and how it has a wide variety of of sophisticated software available - important things like financial management package...<br><br> He just challenged me to a game of Protector.<br><br> That's my Dad. I love him, but sometimes I wish he could understand how a kid feels.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this funky ??!! I love it. We can see here the handle of the H1.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (MAY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>No info in this advert about the display that could be used (TV, composite, colour, B/W?)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">What in the name of Adam do people do with Apple computers?<br> You tell us.<br> In a thousand of words or less.<br> If your story is original and intriguing enough, you can win a one-week trip to Hawaii. Which is the closest we could come to paradise.</font><br><br> Unfortunately, the contest ended March 31, 1980... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> XEROX RANGE, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - HAPPY COUPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - FEB.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (APR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the time of this advert (September 1980), Heathkit introduced a music synthetiser board, a speech lab, a color graphic board, a color monitor and Microsoft BASIC and FORTRAN languages. </blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Video chip compatible with the Texas Instruments TMS 9918/A or TMS 9928/A (Japan : 60 Hz) or TMS 9929/A (Europe : 50 Hz)
computer.description:
Classic MSX 1 computer with 32 KB RAM and two cartridge slots.
More picture in the Panasonic CF-2700 entry. Same machine, but with 64 KB of RAM.

emulator.description: A Bresilian MSX Emulator written in 100% assembler
emulator.name: BrMSX

emulator.description: A MSX Emulator for Win95 and Win NT + Direct X
emulator.name: RuMSX

emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.
emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.

Panasonic FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br> It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br> Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>
